A quiet power is held by certain numbers that may be said to drive and underpin American policies on every front, more so than the reasoning and character of words. Crunch the numbers. Connect the dots. With America’s proven oil reserves standing near 30 bbls, and consumption running near 7 bbls annually; it is self-evident that "without imports" the nation's current consumption, economy and way of life may only be self-sustained for five short years. Five years? Then what?

Regardless then of words, beliefs or rhetoric, these numbers quietly speak louder than the most powerful narrative. As such, the policies, beliefs and constitution of a great nation are today held hostage by numbers that cannot be fixed by known measures of science, technology or economic growth. Such is their quiet power....

I'd be more interested in seeing a hub for "green" energy and transportation technology develop in Manhattan; as far as energy use and pollution control is concerned, NYC could be looked at like its own, contained research lab. You have the changing weather in Upstate to work with. The Northeast Corridor is a perpetual congestion jam, waiting for any sensible relief. Can plants and algae be propagated in the sewers from hanging beds, reducing pollution? Subway hanging gardens? Could filtration systems be built under sidewalks that filter exhaust from traffic and/or could circulate air from the waterfront, cooling buildings and streets in doing so? Is there a niche for developing the best technology for maintaining green, "living" walls and "backup" passive, kinetic energy systems? And most importantly for societal change: How can we make such technology pretty and familiar? How do we appeal to an aesthetic mentality that wants to see rose gardens, marble halls and Art Deco inspired, architectural dentalwork?

This is where our future success as a nation will be found. These are the products that people, from around The World, will desire and pay for -- now, and far into The Future. And if these particular industries do take-off into a growth boom, it will be a win for everyone. Plus, it's novel and "ahead of the times" -- a concept that's always been compatible with the spirit of the city. Do something new and cool, again, NYC. Make things interesting for the rest of us.

The difference between NY and Silicon Valley/Bay Area is the mindset. New Yorkers think they ARE the world. Whereas people in the Bay Area want to CHANGE the world. People come to the Bay Area for a cause, to find themselves, to escape the establishment. No one cares about how much money you have or how big your house is. People could care less if you dress nice. You can be a billionaire and wear a hoodie and running shoes everyday in the Bay Area (as Mark Zuckerberg does). In NY if you're not wearing the right clothes no one takes you seriously. In the Bay Area if your wearing a suit in the office your either there to fix the copier or to peddle office supplies. I don't own a suit and don't know anyone who does, even the bankers here wear dockers and button down shirts.

"silicon valley" isn't a city and i doubt any city can compete with it. it's a sprawling area with lots of giant office parks. maybe somewhere outside nyc can try to compete but the city itself isn't going to be able to. that said, people here can't imagine living with nyc's climate of extremely uncomfortable summers and winters, and they don't want to give up the natural beauty and extensive outdoor activities of the bay area for an overwhelmingly built environment.

if any region is a competitor, it is not nyc but, obviously, the seattle area, with microsoft in redmond and amazon and many others. the climate is mild there year round, but the bay area has way more sunshine.

also, the tech culture has a big component of living relatively modestly, where nyc seems to be all about flaunting status symbols. most techies aren't comfortable with that; there is a contingent that is but if they wanted to live in status symbol-oriented area they would move down to los angeles, which has much natural beauty and a mostly lovely climate.

I tend to agree with your recommendations. There's a certain dynamic in Silicon Valley that is a function of the number of people working on new things and the number of people looking to fund new things and the culture that glues them all together. NY might find that investing in education just sends more people to Silicon Valley after they graduate.

California produces the technological innovations and New York produces the leeches that trade on those ideas.  That's about as likely to change as the weather on either coast.  Speaking of which, don't underestimate the California sunshine.  Nobody ever moved to NYC for the weather.

New York sorely needs more entrepreneurial engineers. Designers and venture capitalists are a dime a dozen, but there is no one who knows how to really squeeze something novel out of a computer. Most of the technical folk here are buttoned down in finance IT support jobs, which is a markedly different mentality to starting something new.

Venture capital is overrated. There are big piles of it lying around. The limiting factor is really good ideas for startup companies and the entrepreneurs to execute them.

I've heard the "NY advantage in fashion, media, music, etc" meme before and am skeptical because these "strengths" can all be summarized in one word:  Content. And the relationship between Content and new technologies is difficult at best. Technology and its proponents from Napster to Craigslist to Google have really upturned the music, film, newspaper, and publishing industries. Now there are upsides, such as the fact that it's easier for anyone to get their content published through YouTube, blogs, etc. But the downside is that the financial models for Content companies have really been upended. 

Recall that Bloomberg's goal is to help create the next wildly successful company like Google or Facebook. But given how the Internet revolution has decimated the bottom lines of music, newspaper, and other Content companies, I fail to see how NY's strengths in these areas will help it become the next Silicon Valley by creating some Google-like success in the Content business. Rather, the Internet ethos of "Information wants to be free" seems to be the opposite of how the NY media establishment generates profits, and the actions they take in response may unintentionally end up crippling the development of a NY tech-Content cluster. 

Ironically enough, the companies that have done the best in marrying content and technology are digital animation companies like Pixar, PDI-Dreamworks, and Lucasfilm-ILM, all three of which are in the Bay Area.

For what it's worth, today I turned down a job offer in New York in favor of remaining in northern California.  Bottom line -- however much I liked the company (and it was a so-so offer), I don't like New York.  Not one bit.  I don't like the prospect of paying $5,000 for a one bedroom apartment.  I don't like the weather.  And I don't like the in-the-box thinking of Wall Street.  Silicon Valley is where it's at!

Which city will be the next Silicon Valley? Shanghai maybe? Singapore? Jakarta? Entrepreneurial innovation does not much require city policy to promote it; it requires national policy that supports and celebrates investment, along with leadership that elevates optimism and risk-taking. America has ceded these values, consigning its former broad vision of possibility to a dark tunnel with an on-rushing train barreling in from the other end.

these so-called luxury goods are now a global commodity, something like McDonalds, and cater to the rich and affluent all over the globe. These global elites fly in and out the States, so the luxury stores have a much larger demand than before, making it possible for them to raise their prizes. In addition, many of these new global elites hardly have the education, taste, style or personal identity to distinguish between this product and that product, making it easier for them to grab something from the shelves of these prefab brand-name luxury stores that you in fact now can find in every major city around the globe. Like I said, something like McDonalds.

Did the stock market just now realize that we have articulated no concrete plan for repaying our national debt?  Everyone wants a handout, and no one wants his  taxes raised.  And for generations now our political leaders have pandered to this manichean mindset of the citizenry.  Sooner or later someone is going to realize that the naked Emperor is the economy.

The fact that the debt ceiling was raised confirmed that by 2020 the USA will be crushed by its childish debt.  Similar to a millionaire's son who abuses drugs, we are a rich country unwilling to be responsible, to think of our future.  Instead, others will control our future, namely China and India.  It was our choice not to balance the federal budget.  The USA is no longer safe to HQ major businesses or employ people.  Elsewhere it is safer and more secure.  As Obama dismantles the institutions that made America a predictable and stable place for business, our economy begins to resemble less successful countries that never had those institutions... like property rights...  a stable currency...  the ability to export.  Since other countries pervert their currencies, and meanwhile profiteers take most tax revenue through medical and military channels, Obama can only throw up his hands, powerless, as the economy goes away, perhaps forever.
